awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Algebraic Methods for Core Problems in Algorithms and Complexity
awd_abstract_narration:
This project targets a number of challenging problems in Algorithms and Complexity that are amenable to an algebraic approach. Research is organized around three major goals: 

1. Algorithms for matrix multiplication with the aim of achieving nearly-linear running time (i.e., proving that the matrix multiplication exponent equals 2).

2. Algorithms for polynomial factorization with the aim of achieving nearly-linear running time, and 

3. Explicit constructions of randomness extractors with the aim of achieving logarithmic seed length and optimal output length. 

A secondary aim of this project is to explicitly cultivate novel algebraic methods with broader applicability, and the choice of problems and approaches is made with this in mind. 

Matrix multiplication is a central open problem in theoretical computer science, and improved algorithms for this important problem would have immediate consequences for a broad array of related problems. Univariate polynomial factorization is a similarly fundamental operation on polynomials, and it stands out as one of a very few such problems for which nearly-linear time algorithms are not yet known. Randomness extractors are unbalanced bipartite graphs with random-like properties that have emerged as a fundamental object in theoretical computer science (and beyond) with a huge array of applications spanning Complexity, Algorithms, Distributed Systems, Cryptography, Coding Theory, Compressed Sensing, and other areas. Resolving fundamental open problems such as those targeted in this project enhances our understanding and mastery of efficient computation.

por.por_cntn:
One of the main focus areas of this project was the development of a mathematical and algorithmic framework for the purpose of devising a so-called "exponent 2" algorithm for matrix multiplication. This is a fundamental problem that lies at the core of many other, seemingly unrelated problems in diverse areas. A well-known open problem is to obtain this conjectured optimal algorithm. Our work under this award has significantly developed a novel approach that imports the problem into the domain of group-theory and representation theory, and brings to bear the mathematical tools from those areas. In particular we have established that a certain type of embedding into an algebraic/combinatorial object called a "coherent configuration" would suffice to obtain an exponent 2 algorithm. There is substantial technical work needed to reach this point, and this was one of the main acheivements of work under this award. In addition we discovered and substantiated unexpected connections between matrix multiplication and famous problems in combinatorics concerning set configurations called sunflowers. This provides insight into hurdles the matrix multiplication work must overcome, and also exposes novel questions in combinatorics. 

Other  work on core problems also yielded the best-known construction of objects called "randomness extractors" which have found applications in many areas of computer science and beyond. In addition we discovered links betweeen a major question regarding the power of quantum computation, and a natural problem in the theory of pseudo-randomness, and with this new motivating application in mind, we made some progress toward resolving the latter question.

The award supported technical collaborations, a number of plenary talks by the PI to diverse audiences, graduate students, and undergraduate research.

Modified by: Christopher M Umans
